"**You 've Really Got a Hold on Me**" is a song written by [Smokey
Robinson](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson "Smokey Robinson") which became a 1962 Top 10
[hit single](/wiki/Hit_single "Hit single") for [The
Miracles](/wiki/The_Miracles "The Miracles") on [Motown](/wiki/Motown
"Motown")'s Tamla label. One of the Miracles' most covered tunes, this
million-selling song received a 1998 [Grammy Hall of Fame
Award](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame_Award "Grammy Hall of Fame Award"). It has
also been selected as one of [The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that
Shaped Rock and
Roll](/wiki/The_Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame%27s_500_Songs_that_Shaped_Rock_and_Roll
"The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll"). It
was covered by English rock group [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The
Beatles") on their second album, _[With the Beatles](/wiki/With_the_Beatles
"With the Beatles")_ and many other musicians.

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Composition")]

"You've Really Got a Hold On Me" was written by [Smokey
Robinson](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson "Smokey Robinson")[1] while in New York in
1962 on business for Motown; he heard [Sam Cooke](/wiki/Sam_Cooke "Sam
Cooke")'s "[Bring It On Home to Me](/wiki/Bring_It_On_Home_to_Me "Bring It On
Home to Me")", which was in the charts at the time, and — influenced by it —
wrote the song in his hotel room.[2]

##
Recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Recording")]

The song was recorded in Motown's Studio A on October 16, 1962 with Robinson
on lead vocals, and Miracles' second tenor [Bobby Rogers](/wiki/Bobby_Rogers
"Bobby Rogers") on harmony co-lead. Robinson was the producer, and he had
[Eddie Willis](/wiki/Eddie_Willis "Eddie Willis") and Miracle [Marv
Tarplin](/wiki/Marv_Tarplin "Marv Tarplin") share the guitar parts.[2]

## Originally a "B"
Side[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Originally a "B" Side")]

The song was released on the Tamla label on November 9, 1962 as the B side to
"[Happy Landing](/wiki/Happy_Landing "Happy Landing")". "Happy Landing"
charted regionally; however, the nation's Dee-Jays flipped the record over,
because they liked "Hold On Me" better.[3] With "You've Really Got a Hold on
Me" as the A side, the single reached the Top 10 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") Pop chart, peaking at number
eight, and was a number-one smash on the Billboard [R&B singles
chart](/wiki/Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs "Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs") during the
winter of 1962-63.[4] The Miracles' original version is a 1998 [Grammy Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame "Grammy Hall of Fame") inductee. It was also
the group's second single to sell over a million copies, after "Shop
Around".[5] It was included on the [album](/wiki/LP_album "LP album") _[The
Fabulous Miracles](/wiki/The_Fabulous_Miracles "The Fabulous Miracles")_ over
three months after its release.

### Soundtracks and film
appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Soundtracks and film appearances")]

The Miracles can be seen performing the song live on stage at the Apollo
Theatre in New York (1963) on the Motown/Universal DVD release: _Smokey
Robinson & The Miracles: [The Definitive Performances
1963-1987](/wiki/The_Definitive_Performances_1963-1987 "The Definitive
Performances 1963-1987")_. This filmed performance, according to the DVD's
liner notes, is the only known recorded live footage of the group with
original Miracles member Claudette (Mrs. Smokey) Robinson. They also performed
it live at the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium the following year (1964) for the
[American International Pictures](/wiki/American_International_Pictures
"American International Pictures") concert film, _[T.A.M.I.
Show](/wiki/T.A.M.I._Show "T.A.M.I. Show")_. It was also chosen for the
soundtrack of the award-winning 1964 [Ivan Dixon](/wiki/Ivan_Dixon "Ivan
Dixon") film, _[Nothing But a Man](/wiki/Nothing_But_a_Man "Nothing But a
Man")_ , and many others (see below). Smokey Robinson himself also performed a
rewritten version of it on _[Sesame Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame
Street")_ alongside a grabby, feminine-looking Muppet letter "U", who wouldn't
stop trying to grab Smokey, with such lyrics as "U stands for uptight/That's
how I'm feelin'/Bein' grabbed by a letter is/Unappealin'". The Miracles
performed the song on a 1964 telecast of the
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
television series _[Shindig!](/wiki/Shindig! "Shindig!")_ , and in 1983, the
group also performed it, 21 years after they originally recorded it, on the
Emmy-winning [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") Television special, _[Motown 25:
Yesterday, Today, Forever](/wiki/Motown_25:_Yesterday,_Today,_Forever "Motown
25: Yesterday, Today, Forever")_.

##

### The
Beatles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: The Beatles")]

"You Really Got a Hold on Me"  
---

from the album _[With the Beatles](/wiki/With_the_Beatles "With the Beatles")_  
Released|  November 22, 1963  
Recorded|  July 18, 1963,  
[EMI Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios "Abbey Road Studios"),
[London](/wiki/London "London")  
[Genre](/wiki/Music_genre "Music genre")|  [Rhythm and
blues](/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues "Rhythm and blues")  
Length|  3:01  
[Label](/wiki/Record_label "Record label")|  [Parlophone](/wiki/Parlophone
"Parlophone")  
[Songwriter(s)](/wiki/Songwriter "Songwriter")|  [Smokey
Robinson](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson "Smokey Robinson")  
[Producer(s)](/wiki/Record_producer "Record producer")|  [George
Martin](/wiki/George_Martin "George Martin")  
  
"You Really Got a Hold on Me" [_[sic](/wiki/Sic "Sic")_] was the first track
recorded for [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' second United
Kingdom LP, _[With the Beatles](/wiki/With_the_Beatles "With the Beatles")_ ,
and features [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon") and [George
Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison") on lead vocals with [Paul
McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") on harmony vocals.[6] The
Beatles acquired an imported copy by the Miracles and included it in their
repertoire early in 1963.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In a 1968 interview, Smokey Robinson reported
that he liked their cover.[1]

The Beatles recorded the song on July 18, 1963. This session took place while
_[Please Please Me](/wiki/Please_Please_Me "Please Please Me")_ was still at
number one in the album charts four months after its release, and in the midst
of a rigorous touring schedule that also had to include [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")
sessions for radio and television. It was completed in seven takes, four of
which were complete. The group then recorded four edit pieces. The final
version was an edit of takes 7, 10 and 11.[7]

The Beatles also recorded "You Really Got a Hold on Me" on four occasions for
BBC radio in 1963. One of these, from July 30, 1963 was included on the _[Live
at the BBC](/wiki/Live_at_the_BBC_\(The_Beatles_album\) "Live at the BBC \(The
Beatles album\)")_ collection. A live version recorded in
[Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") in
October 1963 was released in 1995 on _[Anthology 1](/wiki/Anthology_1
"Anthology 1")_. The song was performed once again in 1969, during the _[Let
It Be](/wiki/Let_It_Be "Let It Be")_ recording sessions, and featured in the
1970 documentary film, _[Let It Be](/wiki/Let_It_Be_\(film\) "Let It Be
\(film\)")_.

### Other
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=You%27ve_Really_Got_a_Hold_on_Me&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Other versions")]

"You've Really Got a Hold on Me" has been covered extensively since its
release: [The Supremes](/wiki/The_Supremes "The Supremes") did a version which
was produced by [Berry Gordy](/wiki/Berry_Gordy "Berry Gordy") with [Hal
Davis](/wiki/Hal_Davis "Hal Davis") and Marc Gordon doing the mixing, and
appeared on their 1964 album _[A Bit of Liverpool](/wiki/A_Bit_of_Liverpool "A
Bit of Liverpool")_.[8] Group member [Mary
Wilson](/wiki/Mary_Wilson_\(singer\) "Mary Wilson \(singer\)") sang in close
unison with [Diana Ross](/wiki/Diana_Ross "Diana Ross")'s lead[9] in their
version.[The Temptations](/wiki/The_Temptations "The Temptations")' version,
produced by Smokey Robinson, was included on their 1965 album _[The
Temptations Sing Smokey](/wiki/The_Temptations_Sing_Smokey "The Temptations
Sing Smokey")_. [Eddie Kendricks](/wiki/Eddie_Kendricks "Eddie Kendricks")
sang lead vocal with [David Ruffin](/wiki/David_Ruffin "David Ruffin")
providing harmony co-lead vocal on verses 1 and 2; [Paul
Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(The_Temptations\) "Paul Williams \(The
Temptations\)") provided vocals on close harmony on the final verse. [The
Zombies](/wiki/The_Zombies "The Zombies") covered the song in their 1965 debut
LP _[Begin Here](/wiki/Begin_Here "Begin Here")_.[10] [Barbara
McNair](/wiki/Barbara_McNair "Barbara McNair") recorded an unreleased version
in 1968, and in 1969 the [Jackson 5](/wiki/Jackson_5 "Jackson 5"), with
[Michael Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson") singing lead,[11]
recorded an unreleased track that was originally intended for their first
album _[Diana Ross Presents The Jackson
5](/wiki/Diana_Ross_Presents_The_Jackson_5 "Diana Ross Presents The Jackson
5")_. Laura Nyro recorded the song in 1971 on her album, _[Gonna Take a
Miracle](/wiki/Gonna_Take_a_Miracle "Gonna Take a Miracle")_. Michael Jackson
also recorded a solo version in 1973; however this remained unreleased until
1984's _[Farewell My Summer Love](/wiki/Farewell_My_Summer_Love "Farewell My
Summer Love")._ These versions were among the first recorded that did not have
dueling unison leads.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [Small Faces](/wiki/Small_Faces "Small Faces") covered the song for their
album _[From the Beginning](/wiki/From_the_Beginning_\(Small_Faces_album\)
"From the Beginning \(Small Faces album\)")_ in 1967.

[Eddie Money](/wiki/Eddie_Money "Eddie Money") covered this song on his 1977
[debut album](/wiki/Eddie_Money_\(album\) "Eddie Money \(album\)").

[Bernard Edwards](/wiki/Bernard_Edwards "Bernard Edwards") covered the song on
his solo album _Glad To Be Here_ in 1983.

[Country music](/wiki/Country_music "Country music") artist [Mickey
Gilley](/wiki/Mickey_Gilley "Mickey Gilley") covered the song in 1984.
Produced by [Jim Ed Norman](/wiki/Jim_Ed_Norman "Jim Ed Norman"), and released
by [Epic Records](/wiki/Epic_Records "Epic Records"), Gilley's version peaked
at #2 on the _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard
\(magazine\)")_ [Hot Country Singles](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country
Songs") chart and #1 on the _[RPM](/wiki/RPM_\(magazine\) "RPM \(magazine\)")_
Country Tracks chart in Canada.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Mike and the Mechanics](/wiki/Mike_and_the_Mechanics "Mike and the
Mechanics") covered the song for their album _[Beggar on a Beach of
Gold](/wiki/Beggar_on_a_Beach_of_Gold "Beggar on a Beach of Gold")_ in 1995.

[Cyndi Lauper](/wiki/Cyndi_Lauper "Cyndi Lauper") covered the song for her
2003 studio album _[At Last](/wiki/At_Last_\(Cyndi_Lauper_album\) "At Last
\(Cyndi Lauper album\)")_.

[She & Him](/wiki/She_%26_Him "She & Him") covered the song on their debut
album _[Volume One](/wiki/Volume_One_\(She_%26_Him_album\) "Volume One \(She &
Him album\)")_ in 2008.

[Rod Stewart](/wiki/Rod_Stewart "Rod Stewart") covered it as well for his
album [Soulbook](/wiki/Soulbook "Soulbook") in 2009.

[Phil Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil Collins") covered the song for his
album _[Going Back](/wiki/Going_Back_\(album\) "Going Back \(album\)")_ in
2010.

[Haley Reinhart](/wiki/Haley_Reinhart "Haley Reinhart") covered the song in an
American Idol performance in 2011.

Smokey Robinson himself also performed a rewritten version of it on _[Sesame
Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame Street")_ in 1985 alongside a grabby
feminine looking Muppet red letter "U", with such lyrics as "U stands for
uptight/That's how I'm feelin'/Bein' grabbed by a letter is/Unappealin'".[12]

[Jinkx Monsoon](/wiki/Jinkx_Monsoon "Jinkx Monsoon") covered the song in their
album [The Ginger Snapped](/wiki/The_Ginger_Snapped "The Ginger Snapped") in
2018
